sp.p: Then come to my rescue, and save your son-in-law from total annihilation !

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: My son-in-law ? what son-in-law ?

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: Why, me to be sure—Peregrine Popplewig ?

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: (aside) Third broadside ! it'll be all over with me in a minute.

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: Three Popplewigs ? it's perfectly phenomenal!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: That's the genuine one, I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: (aside) It's the young man who wanted me to walk to Bognor.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: Let me out, for mercy's sake let me out—your pigeon-house is full of rats ! they're beginning at my toes already, and if you don't let me out there'll be nothing left of me in half-an-hour but my braces !

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Don't let him out—let the rats devour him ! he deserves it, the reprobate, for coming here to marry your daughter when he is already bound to another by a chain of roses.

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: He's married ?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I said a chain of roses, Mr. Biffin.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: Help! help! I've got a rat in my waistcoat pocket!

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: There's the key, Marchioness. (gives key to Soph.)

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I've a great mind to keep him there a little longer among the rats, only I can't afford to have him damaged, so I'll be merciful though he doesn't deserve it. (goes up to pigeon-house)

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: Now perhaps you'll furnish me with an explanation of your conduct, Mr. Walker.

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: Don't call me Walker—I'm no more Walker than I am Popplewig.

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: Then who the devil are you ? some nameless adventurer, I'll answer for it.

div.stage: Enter Arabella, L.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Yes brother, an adventurer who has been tracked here by the police.

sp.speaker: Bif.Pop.Simon.Clara.Soph.
sp.p: The police!

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: (aside) What the deuce is she talking about ? I always keep clear of the police, just to aggravate them.

div.stage: Enter Toby Trot, C. from L.

sp.speaker: Trot.
sp.p: There's the drab coat—I've got him!

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: (aside) He's found me out, and I shall be sent to prison for poaching.

sp.speaker: Trot.
sp.p: (going to Simon) Ah ! I knew I should catch you at last, my lad, so now come along with me. (collars Simon)

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Simon!

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: What, Simon Slowboy.

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: (aside) The tables are turning—bravo !

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Yes, it's me, and he's caught me.

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: And you had the audacity to attempt to pass yourself off for Mr. Popplewig, young man.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Why, you see Mr. Biffin, it wasn't quite the thing, I know, but Miss Arabella led me to hope —

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: That will do Simon, we don't want any explanation, (to Trot) I'll be answerable for this gentleman—we'll pay you whatever you require.

sp.speaker: Trot.
sp.p: Oh of course, if you're going to come down with the ready, that's perfectly satisfactory—I'll wait outside till you're disengaged.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: (coming out of pigeon-house) Here I am, father-in-law, and safe and sound too, for a wonder. How d'ye do ? (offers his hand to Biffin)

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: (pushing him away) Stop a minute, let's have all this cleared up first.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: There's nothing wants clearing up— I've come to marry your daughter, hand her over, there's an end of the matter.

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: That's impossible, for I'm going to marry her myself.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: You marry my daughter ? never !

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: I've got your promise in writing. Mr. Biffin, of course you'll honour your signature.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: (to Popplewig) What, you've the audacity to say such a thing before my very face.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: (to Naggins) Marry Sophonisba if you like—her father won't object, I'll answer for it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Monster!

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: I've settled the whole affair with Miss Biffin—she has given her consent.

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: Arabell— Is it possible ?

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: And in writing too—I can show it to you if you like, (to Arabella) Shall I show it to him ?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: It's quite unnecessary.

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: (aside) What a rage she's in.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: (crossing to C.) It's perfectly true, brother Bartholomew—this gentleman has given me such overwhelming reasons for approving of the match, that I couldn't possibly withhold my consent.

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: That may be, but I've pledged my word; and besides, I'm sure Clara prefers Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: Of course she does, (to Clara) Don't you prefer Peregrine ?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: On the contrary, papa, I wouldn't marry him for the world.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Bravo! that's a settler!

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: But I don't even know his name.

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: Never mind, you'll hear it when we publish the banns.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: (to Naggins) Don't imagine that I'm going to put up with this quietly, Sir—I shall expect your friend tomorrow between twelve and one.

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: Very good, where shall he call upon you ?

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: At New York—I'll go back there directly.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: We'll go back together, Peregrine, when you've given me your hand.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: You shall have it Sophonisba—I'll get it cast in plaster, and send it to you by the Parcels Delivery.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Don't be a fool, Peregrine ! I've got you, and I'll hold you fast this time, depend upon it. (takes his arm)

sp.speaker: Nag.
sp.p: (to Biffin) Come, shake hands, father-in-law— it's no use grumbling, you see there's no help for it.

sp.speaker: Bif.
sp.p: Well, I suppose I must consent; but if I am to have you for a son-in-law, I'll give up being a peaceable man for the rest of my life. (shakes hands with Naggins)

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p:
]That's right, make the best of what you can't
help—it's the wisest plan. Well, I've made a capital day's work of it—I've secured a nice little wife and a snug little fortune, and all through aggravation! I've found my happiness as they find coal—by boring for it. (to Audience)] Only look at them all—don't they look miserable ? and no wonder, for I've aggravated them horribly! Old Biffin's vexed because he's got a son-in-law that he doesn't like— Arabella's plagued because I've found her out and marred all her plans—Simon's annoyed because he hasn't got the wife he wanted, and Popplewig's worried because he's got the wife he didn't want—and it's all through me! How they must love me ! There's one thing I hope though, and that is, I haven't bored you: I'm an aggravating fellow, I know, but I mean to reform—I'm going to turn over a new leaf and lead a model life, but before I begin I should like one last bit of aggravation. I want to persuade you to applaud this piece—not for the sake of the author, I don't care a button for him—but on account of his rivals—they will be so frightfully aggravated. Will you oblige me ?— Thank you!

div.stage: Curtain.
